column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=4. Discussion

#Text=We reviewed for the first time the studies concerning the relation between macrostructural and/or microstructural features of sleep and ADHD , considering the investigations of the last 15 years .
#Text=4.1. Macrostructural Pattern
#Text=The results concerning the macrostructural parameters are quite conflicting , and drawing a coherent framework is challenging .
#Text=Almost half of the selected studies did not find differences in the sleep architecture of children with ADHD , compared to those with typical development .
#Text=The investigations revealing significant differences between the ADHD and HC groups demonstrated that the clinical samplea are characterized by poorer sleep than controls .

#Text=Indeed , the longer SOL , the shorter TST , along with the reduced SE and the indices of faster transition of stages/cycles ( e.g. , a higher rate of SS and a greater number of sleep cycles ) reflect -to some extent- the sleep dysregulation in ADHD .

#Text=On the one hand , the assumption that children with ADHD have an altered sleep architecture is consistent with the subjective parent reports , mentioning a delayed sleep onset or a sleep fragmentation with several night awakenings .
#Text=On the other hand , the sleep difficulties reported by parents appear to be significantly higher as compared to objective measures .
#Text=The gap between subjective and objective measures may be ascribed to other factors that cannot be revealed by the PSG recordings .

#Text=The subjective reports of increased SOL — confirmed only by some investigations using objective measures ( e.g. , ) — may be explained by “ behavioral ” sleep problems occurring before bedtime .

#Text=In this regard , the bedtime resistance could depend on multiple factors : ( a ) inadequate parenting ; ( b ) Inadequate pre-sleep bed routines and/or sleep environment ; ( c ) pharmacotherapy side-effects .
#Text=This disturbance in ADHD children is often interpreted as oppositional behavior , a significant source of distress for parents .
#Text=In light of the above , it is fair to assume that subjective reports could overestimate sleep problems in ADHD , reflecting parental concerns .
#Text=NREM sleep architecture did not show specific and consistent differences between children with ADHD and HC .
#Text=We have to underline that a lower SWS has been found in an ADHD sample characterized by a higher rate of comorbidities or when a higher apnea-hypopnea index was detected .
#Text=In this respect , a strong relationship between SDB and ADHD behavior was found ( e.g. , ) , likely inducing the disruption of sleep homeostasis and less deep sleep .
#Text=Moreover , as previously mentioned , the exclusion of subjects with externalizing and internalizing problems from the analysis abolished all differences in NREM sleep .

#Text=Although no other differences in SWS were found , it should be underlined that both stage 4 amount and REM sleep density were correlated with the improvement in motor skills performance after sleep in children with ADHD , as assessed by Prehn-Kristensen et al. .
#Text=This study suggested a possible beneficial role of sleep on tasks measuring procedural memory in ADHD , that – instead- showed compromised performance during the waking state .
#Text=REM sleep abnormalities seem to be widespread among children with ADHD , consistently with previous meta-analysis .
#Text=REM sleep alterations could be related to the dysfunctional reward learning , one of the core deficits of ADHD , due to the dopamine hypofunction .
#Text=Specifically , several findings highlighted that REM sleep duration is longer in children with ADHD compared to controls , and only Gruber et al. found a reduced amount of REM sleep in ADHD .
#Text=It is worth noting that this latter study included patients with PLMS that may induce REM sleep instability , contributing to its shorter duration .
#Text=Interestingly , the higher REM sleep percentage in the ADHD group was found along with a higher number of sleep cycles in two studies .
#Text=As already suggested , the increased number of sleep cycles may result in a faster transition to REM sleep , contributing to the increased REM sleep amount .
#Text=Once again , the presence of comorbidities could have affected these results .
#Text=4.2.
#Text=Microstructural Pattern
#Text=Concerning the eight studies reporting sleep microstructural features in the ADHD group , the results are not homogenous .
#Text=Findings on spindle activity are still scarce and very difficult to interpret .

#Text=In particular , some methodological differences in the spindle analysis should be taken into account : ( a ) Saletin et al. did not provide a specific spindle detection , analyzing the whole sigma band ; ( b ) some protocols did not include parietal derivations , where the spindles typically show their maximum .
#Text=The most relevant alterations in sleep microstructure of ADHD are related to SWA and theta activity during NREM and REM sleep , respectively .
